I have lots more to talk about this and you can check our https://t.co/wPhNfyEEdQ blog posts on that. Know this, it's super important to have an open and grounded convo w your att'y AND accountant about your revenue model. If I'm gonna be that person, please bring graphics. üòÖ

If this distribution is properly made, the entity doesn't pay taxes on the part of the surplus that is distributed. The members receiving the patronage returns are responsible for their own taxes over that amount. The entity does issue a 1099-PATR at that point. No double tax.

In a coop, if there are profits left at the end (i.e surplus) generated by the activities of the members (in the offer of good/services), then that amount is distributable to the members as patronage returns also known as patronage dividends. Yes, the member gets two payments.
On the entity side, payment for those are a cost. It comes out of the revenue. Entity typically generates revenue by providing goods/services to its customers and then covers the costs.

In my DAO coop work I hear a lot about patronage, & I still don't think we talk about it enough, in terms of legal implications. 
While work, services, contribution can def be patronage activities, these must be compensated for the original labels they have: work, services, etc.

@GeorgeGoognin For now, I'm just saying that DAOs are not exempt from 1099 requirements just because they are paying in tokens/property.

‚ùì of the day: If a DAO pays you more than $600 during the year (accumulated amount), the DAO should be issuing you a 1099. If you are bartering with the DAO and/or other members, a 1099 might need to be issued in some cases too. Blog post coming soon!

@economic_lab @ajscholz Not sure if we have, but I'll look for it. I do think that's a feature of limited cooperative associations (LCAs), which is a regular use in our practice, & most practitioners and professionals are not familiar with it.

@dapperjman Some states have laws that treat them as "nonprofit" entities (not 501c3), but it's bc they're not created for the profit of the entity, but for the benefit of its members. Any profits are typically allocated to the members as patronage dividends, based on the member's activities
@ajscholz Technically, cooperatives can have voting based on patronage activity, and that's what I'm seeing DAOs adopt.
